Dear Michelle Seigo:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
May 14, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS

• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned changed.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, stepdown
from a residential or hospital setting, return from
AWOLP, or request for change in foster home/relative
placements.
Four of six foster care files reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/16/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 4/11/2023

FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider
• Youth adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management record.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child’s current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is temporary
court ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-home
placement. At reunification. Subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
• Non-offending parent, subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and accepted
for treatment or services prior to or at the first
schedule appointment while the foster care case
is open, regardless of placement. Subsequent
medical passports are not required.
Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
aged 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (youth adults
aged 18 and older).
• YAVFC youth/young adult.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and required
signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/16/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 4/11/2023

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency Renewal inspection was completed on 3/16/23 and the CAP was
approved on 4/11/23. The agency was cited for 7 violations, 7 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 7, there was an improvement in individual incidents of
non-compliance within 4 of the violation areas (foster parent information, visitation
and parenting time, FTM documentation and medical passports) and a slight
increase in number of individual incidents in the other 3 areas (supervisor
approval, PATP's, and FTM's). In 2022, 16 violations were established, 5 of which
were repeated this year. All of the repeated violations remain close to the number
of individual incidents of non-compliances except for an increase in FTM's and
PATP's and a decrease in medical passports. The agency will need to establish
additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a reduction of
incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the CAP that is in place has been effective. However, they have had a
lot of difficult cases with multiple placement changes, and they assisted another
office and inherited challenging cases from them as well. In addition, there have
been some staff that went out on leave which also impacted overall compliance.
The chief administrator reported the agency has worked diligently to provide
supports to placements, caregivers, youth and parents as well as their staff.
9

Financial Overview
N/A
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors are available to assist as needed, however
there is room for improvement among the staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. Records are stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
